The reasoning behind the safety-first criterion is illustrated in Figure 8. Assume an
investor is choosing between two portfolios: Portfolio A with expected return of 12%
and standard deviation of returns of 18%, and Portfolio B with expected return of 10%
and standard deviation of returns of 12%. The investor has stated that he wants to
minimize the probability of losing money (negative returns). Assuming that returns are
normally distributed, the portfolio with the larger SFR using 0% as the threshold return
(R) will be the one with the lower probability of negative returns.
